awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: A Dynamical Systems Approach to Shepherding and Sorting Microparticles in Fluids
awd_abstract_narration:
Engineering problems requiring the controlled transport and positioning of solid particles suspended in fluids on a microscopic scale arise in contexts ranging from biomedical research to precision manufacturing. Technology enabling particle manipulation without direct mechanical contact between particles and manipulators is required in situations when the particles are fragile (like biological cells) or when high throughput is critical. This award supports fundamental research advancing a strategy whereby slender vibrating probes are used to excite patterns of flow in particle-laden fluids that in turn advect particles in desired ways. Preliminary results indicate that this approach can be used not only to achieve particle transport and positioning but also to separate particles according to physical attributes like size and geometry. The project requires coordinated activity by members of the research team in mathematical, computational, and experimental domains. Outcomes from this activity will include both scientific results with diverse practical implications and novel mechanisms for training undergraduate and graduate students across traditional disciplinary lines.

Technical issues to be addressed include the development of mathematical models with varying degrees of detail representing fluid flows near systems of vibrating probes, the development of approximate analytical models for the time-averaged dynamics of inertial particles advected by such flows, and the development of top-level control strategies for archetypical problems in particle transport and sorting. All of these will build upon successful preliminary studies by the project team and will be validated with numerical simulations exploiting high-fidelity computational models and with physical experiments exploiting a unique laboratory platform under development.

por.por_cntn:
Water behaves differently on different physical scales. The aquatic world in which many protozoa live is effectively much more viscous than that experienced by macroscopic marine animals, and microorganisms have to negotiate very different physics in order to accomplish simple tasks like gathering food from their surroundings. Some surmount this challenge by exploiting a phenomenon called viscous streaming, whereby the relatively high-speed beating of cilia can drive relatively low-speed conveyer belt-like patterns of flow that extend far from the cilia themselves, transporting not just fluid but also suspended solid particles along persistent trajectories.

Diverse applications exist for microscopic robotic devices that can reproduce this capability, but the development of such technology requires the means to study particle transport in viscous streaming flows with efficient computer simulations and the means to design control protocols enabling systems of artificial cilia to achieve specific particle-transport goals.

The computational cost of simulating a system's behavior increases with the range of time scales over which its behavior must be represented explicitly. A central outcome of this project was a technique for accurately simulating the slow-scale dynamics of solid particles transported by viscous streaming flows without having to simulate the fast-scale dynamics of the cilia generating the flows themselves. By making it possible to simulate particle transport among arrays of vibrating cilia efficiently, this technique allowed the problem of control design for arrays of artificial cilia to be undertaken via reinforcement learning, a machine learning technique popularly known as the basis for computer programs that outperform humans at board games and video games.

Not only was it possible to demonstrate via simulation that conventional reinforcement learning algorithms could produce effective control policies, but it was also shown that novel variants of such algorithms could produce such policies at an accelerated pace by exploiting physical symmetries, an idea that can be extended to accelerate the realization of control policies for a variety of other robotic systems.
